title: Tsunami Recovery in Four Fishing Villages, India
summary: In order to rebuild the livelihoods of surviving victims and protect children, we provide boats and fishing nets to fishermen; shelter for villagers, especially orphans, and medical/ school supplies.
need: Project is focusing on specific actions for about 300 tsunami victim families in four villages in southern India: three at Karunagapally, Edavanakad, Pallithodu near Kochi, Kerala, one near Chennai, Tamil Nadu (and initially one near Nellore, Andhra Pradesh, component now completed). Villages are located in ex-disaster areas. Fully resuming fishing takes time, and the burden of feeding the family still falls in great part on women. Many families need medical help and children need go to school.
longTermImpact: Positive long-term impact will be the result of prompt action/funding: when a safe environment is re-created with basic needs--proper housing, clean water, tools--people can work again and children can safely go back to school, key for the future.
activities: 1. Distribution of household utensils, kerosene stoves, baby food, clean water, fishing nets, flashlights, medical/school supplies. 2. Volunteer and community assistance to repair fishing boats/engines, build new boats, and train young fishermen

donationOption.description: Provides a fishing net for a fisherman.
Provides a new fishing boat.
Food and necessities for 20 orphans for a month.
Medical/surgical assistance for a child in distress/danger

image.title: Tsunami Recovery in Four Fishing Villages, India

title: Income Recovery for Poor Sri Lankans
summary: To create jobs for the community following widespread Tsunami devastation through entrepreneurship training and microfinance assistance and motivate them to be self reliant.
need:
We will restore the livelihoods of 240 families 5 D.S divisions in the Galle district. 
2. To establish a revolving fund to provide financial assistance to 24 groups in the Galle
    district to re- start their small enterprises. 
3. To update and upgrade the talent and skills of the 24 groups of the backward
  community the Galle district to start and profitably maintain business management. 

 240 families will benefit through this project. In addition 2406 persons also might benefit.
longTermImpact: 240 families will be able to start enterprises and will recover socially and economically. The health, education, environment  and the social status of the community will be restored.
activities: To restore the livelihood of 240 families 5 D.S divisions in the Galle district we will establish a revolving fund to provide financial assistance to 24 groups in the Galle district to re- start their small enterprises.

donationOption.description: Provide one person with entrepreneurship training
Provide one person with home garden development training
Provides a grant to one person to start a small enterprise
Distributes home gardening tools to 140 people

image.title: Income Recovery for Poor Sri Lankans

organization.name: Afghan Institute of Learning
organization.mission: The Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL) works to empower all Afghans who are needy, especially women and children, providing them the knowledge and skills to care for themselves. AIL is expanding access to quality education and healthcare through community based programming, enabling communities to develop the capacity of their people. The goal is to create a foundation of quality education and health systems throughout Afghanistan which meet the needs of local people now and in the future. AIL was founded by an Afghan woman and is run mainly by women, reaching thousands each year through health facilities, educational centers and training programs.

title: Help Desperate Families from Pakistan Disasters
summary: The Afghan Institute of Learning is providing drinking water, food and shelter to Afghan refugees and Pakistanis who have lost everything from last year's earthquake, heavy fighting and now flooding.
need: A huge earthquake, fighting, and now flooding have devastated Afghan refugees living in Pakistan. They have no drinking water, food, shelter or schools.  AIL is working to give refugees food and water, and re-establish shelter.  This fall, AIL will re-open schools for children to begin their education once again.
longTermImpact: Our emergency programs provide sustenance for homeless families and educates the women and children for family support.
activities: Food, water and shelter- these are the basic necessities of living. AIL will deliver these to the camps near Peshawar and will give hope to families with re-opening school.

donationOption.description: feeds two IDPs for 7 days
feed a family of 4 for one week
packet of food for 8 people for 7 days
provides package of dishes for one tent

image.title: Help Desperate Families from Pakistan Disasters

title: Boys & Girls Club of Baton Rouge Katrina Relief
summary: Make a difference in the lives of the children most affected by Katrina by providing a safe place for kids to learn and grow after school, on weekends and in the summer.
need: Of the more than 1 million people displaced by Hurricane Katrina, some 300,000 are children. After the storm, Boys & Girls Club moved quickly to assist children who were forced from their homes. We provide a safe place for kids to recover from the traumatic events, a place to learn, play and make new friends. Currently, there are about 500 displaced kids participating in the programs that will run throughout this school year and next summer.
longTermImpact: Boys & Girls Club is committed to our mission to inspire and enable all young people, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds, to realize their full potential as productive, responsible and caring citizens.
activities: Boys & Girls Club provides after school programs at Scotlandville Middle School and weekend activities at FEMA trailer parks. We are working with other local agencies to assist in the recovery of children and families affected by the storm.

donationOption.description: Pays for a bus driver to deliver students to our programs.
Pays for a program instructor to spend the day with the kids.
Will pay for one art instructor to spend one session with kids participating in our programs.

image.title: Boys & Girls Club of Baton Rouge Katrina Relief

title: Tsunami Recovery in Five Coastal Villages, India
summary: Providing post-tsunami help to 250 villagers, 20 urban families and 25 girl students for livelihoods recovery, home reconstruction, medical care and school enrollment in Kerala and Tamil Nadu, India
need: As relief gives way to the long and difficult process of reconstruction, project is focusing on specific actions for about 400 people to rebuild their life in Chennai and in five tsunami affected villages: two at Challanam/Karunagapally and Edavanakad/Pallithodu near Kochi, Kerala and three at Ambedkar Nagar, Kuppankulam and Pethankuppam near Cuddalore, Tamil Nadu. God-parenthood has a strong impact by helping poor children go back to school and receive medical care on a case by case basis.
longTermImpact: Positive long-term impact is the result of prompt action/funding: when a safe environment is re-created with basic needs--proper housing, clean water, health-- 400 people will live normally again; children will go to school, key for the future.
activities: 1. Providing household utensils, clean water, food supplements, clothes, medical care, school supplies, sewing machines and fishing nets. 2. Repairing and rebuilding homes. 3. Protecting/sponsoring children and helping 25 girls finish high school.

donationOption.description: A sewing machine for one young village woman in Kerala or Tamil Nadu.
Food and necessities for 10 orphans in Kerala for a month.
Sponsoring a poor family as God-parent of one child in need for a year.
Basic health care for 7 children in Kerala and Tamil Nadu for a year.
All necessities/ tuition for 25 tsunami affected girls for a month to help them finish school..
Rebuilding one decent home in a flooded village or area.
Major surgery in a private hospital in Kochi to save the life of a poor child .

image.title: Tsunami Recovery in Five Coastal Villages, India

organization.name: The Citizens Foundation
organization.addressLine1: Plot No. 20, Sector # 14, Near Brookes Chowrangi, Korangi Industrial Area, Karachi, 74900, Pakistan.
organization.mission: The Citizens Foundation's (TCF) mission is to promote mass-scale quality education in Pakistan at the primary and secondary levels in an environment that encourages intellectual, moral and spiritual growth. The aim of the TCF education program is to equip less-privileged children with knowledge and literacy skills, to inculcate in them high moral values and the confidence to strive for their goals.

title: Educating 100 children in earthquake hit areas
summary: This project focuses on rebuilding lives through education by providing high quality primary education to 100 less-privileged children in the earthquake affected areas of Northern Pakistan.
need:
October 2005 earthquake wrought havoc in the lives of millions of inhabitants of Northern Pakistan. Almost all the schools in the worst hit areas were destroyed. TCF is building seismically designed schools in these areas, which will create arenas of hope and provide a safe haven for the vulnerable and poor children in these areas. This project will educate 100 less-
privileged children in Mansehra district at TCF purpose built primary schools.
longTermImpact: The project will educate 100 less-privileged children in the earthquake affected areas of Pakistan, giving them hope and the will to move beyond the tragedy they have faced and break free of the vicious circle of poverty.
activities: TCF will use the funds, which will cover the cost of students’ textbooks, uniforms, school supplies, teachers’ recruitment/training, curriculum planning and evaluation, to pay for 1 year's school fees for 100 most disadvantaged children in the area.

donationOption.description: You can support a child’s education for a month
You can educate a child for a year - pay for text books, uniforms, school supplies, teachers’ recruitment/training,  curriculum planning and supervision
You can educate a class of 30 students for a year

image.title: Educating 100 children in earthquake hit areas

title: Interest-free loans to 150 quake affected women
summary: This project will increase the monthly income of 150 poor women in 4 villages of the earthquake-affected area of Pakistan by an average of $50 by promoting women micro enterprising.
need: This project is based on the Sustainable Human Development focusing on capacity building where 150 women of 4 villages of earthquake-affected area will be provided business skills along with financial assistance to address the problem of rural poverty. As a result of the proposed project women will contribute in income generation and support the family to improve their livelihood.
longTermImpact: The project will increase income level of 150 households which will improve living standard of approx 1050 people (average population / household =7) of the poor families.
activities:
1.developing 200 households’ profiles
2.selecting 150 households 
3.Meetings with community
4.Identification of 10 feasible businesses
5.Conducting 6 trainings in business development for women
6.Providing $170 to each woman
7.Monitoring

donationOption.description: enables a woman to contribute $50 to her family monthly income
enhances the skills of a woman for self-employment
provides a first time interest free loan to a woman in earthquake-affected area of Pakistan so she can start her own business
provides detail feasibility of a business for self-employment to 150 women

image.title: Interest-free loans to 150 quake affected women

organization.name: The Layton Rahmatulla Benevolent Trust
organization.addressLine1: 37 - C Sunset Lane # 4, 24th Commercial Street Phase - II (Ext), Defence Housing Authority
organization.mission: LRBT is committed to creating a better Pakistan by preventing the suffering caused by blindness and other eye ailments. LRBT's mission "No man, woman or child should go blind simply because they cannot afford the treatment"

title: Provide Free Eye Care in a Pakistani Eye Hospital
summary: Provide free eye care in LRBT’s eye hospital in Mansehra. From Nov 2005 to July 31, 2008, 142,565 outpatient procedures and 13,999 major & minor surgeries were performed absolutely free of cost.
need:
Mansehra hospital would cater to eye care needs of a population of over 2.4 million comprising catchment areas of Batgram, Muzaffarabad, Abbotabad and Azad Kashmir.

Estimated number of beneficiaries visiting OPD       200 per day 60,000 per annum

Estimated number of beneficiaries for cataract surgery 40 per day 9,600 per annum

This will benefit a large number of patients whose precarious situation & struggle for survival has been aggravated by the October 2005 earthquake.
longTermImpact: Prevention of Blindness & restoration of sight to blind patients reducing dependence & converting them into productive members of a community which has been shattered by the earthquake
activities:
The hospital will provide diagnostic and curative eyecare needs of patients for: 
•Refractive Errors 
•Cataract
•Glaucoma
•Trachoma
•Trauma
•Lachrymal and Squint Surgery.

donationOption.description: can provide OPD treatment to 10 patients
can restore eye sight to those who have gone blind from cataracts
can cover cost of a Squint Surgery

image.title: Provide Free Eye Care in a Pakistani Eye Hospital

organization.name: Afghan Institute of Learning
organization.mission: The Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL) works to empower all Afghans who are needy, especially women and children, providing them the knowledge and skills to care for themselves. AIL is expanding access to quality education and healthcare through community based programming, enabling communities to develop the capacity of their people. The goal is to create a foundation of quality education and health systems throughout Afghanistan which meet the needs of local people now and in the future. AIL was founded by an Afghan woman and is run mainly by women, reaching thousands each year through health facilities, educational centers and training programs.

title: Emergency Aid for Afghan Families
summary: Poor Afghans in Afghanistan are particularly vulnerable in times of disaster, whether natural or economic. Those without jobs, food or homes face starvation in harsh winter weather or after other natural disasters or following displacement.  In recent years, there have been landslides, earthquakes and flooding incidents where we have been able to provide help.
contactAddress: Afghan Institute of Learning c/o CHI
need: Many poor Afghans live on the edge of family crisis, without a safety net in the harsh winters, let alone should a disaster occur. AIL is able to provide food and relief for these people by having funds to plan ahead and buy provisions, so as to be ready to respond as soon as needed. These funds were most recently put to use in responding to landslide, earthquake and flooding disasters as well as regular food needs .
longTermImpact: The aid provided will help the poor to feed their families, provide fuel for cooking fires and give other assistance as needed, to help people make it through crisis points.
activities: Donations to this project will go towards efforts to provide aid to the most vulnerable in the case of severe weather or disasters. AIL has a team that keeps supplies prepared, monitors weather and is alerted to disasters that occur, including those in more remote areas.

donationOption.description: Provides one emergency packet for a family of four for one month
Provides emergency packets for 2 families or 8 people for one month
Provides emergency packets for 4 families or 16 people for one month

title: Protect 100 acres of vital Australian rainforest
summary: Project is a First Response/Disaster Recovery operation.  (WHL) rainforest and enangered species are in jeopardy.  First responders, care takers, vets and conservationists need your support!
need: The World Heritage Listed tropical rainforest in Australia contains one of the highest numbers of plant and animal species that are threatened with extinction in the world. The Australian Rainforest Foundation is dedicated to habitat rehabilitation, education and research. Land purchase will protect these ancient plants and create wildlife corridors for continued species survival. The rainforest will benefit from this land protection and extension by maintaining its mega biodiversity.
longTermImpact: Preserving this ancient rainforest will give future generations the prospect of new medicines. Protecting this forest will store thousands of tons of carbon in the forest's biomass, and re-vegetating cleared land will give us oxygen.
activities: Purchasing land will ensure its protection as a nature refuge. Extending and repairing the rainforest by planting the right tree in the right place will provide ongoing habitat for rainforest fauna.

donationOption.description: Food for injured/displaced wilife
Vet medicine & drugs for injured wildlife
Basic repairs for hospitals, vet clinics, jeeps, equipment
Emergency surgery on wildlife
Emergency habitat restoration/wildlife corridors

image.title: Protect 100 acres of vital Australian rainforest
